definition: to exaggerate/empty/in vain/old variant of 螗[tang2]
to dash/to move forward quickly/to bulge/to protrude/to break through/to rush out/sudden/Taiwan pr. [tu2]

sentences.chinese: 苏格拉底的作法相对唐突。

sentences.english: It was very abrupt to come home and speak to you all at once.
sentences.chinese: 我一回来就立刻向你提这件事，的确是太唐突了。

sentences.english: But I am afraid of abrupt, heart unexpectedly having infinite timid.
sentences.chinese: 可我怕唐突，心下竟又生起无限怯意。

sentences.english: A: Am I curt with you if I ask you to marry me now?
sentences.chinese: 如果我现在向你求婚，不会太唐突吧？

sentences.english: Excuse me for my abrupt question.
sentences.chinese: 请原谅我这个唐突的问题。
它看起来一点都不唐突。

sentences.english: His tone was characterized by curtness and dryness.
sentences.chinese: 他语气的特点是唐突而又冷淡。

sentences.english: He turned me around again, politely and abruptly.
sentences.chinese: 他又一次把我转过来，礼貌而唐突。

sentences.english: She didn’t think this was an odd request and was happy to oblige me.
sentences.chinese: 她没有觉得这个请求很唐突并且乐意帮我。

sentences.english: The mystery novel came to an abrupt end without explaining the crime.
sentences.chinese: 这个神秘的故事结尾很唐突，对罪行没有什么交代。

definition: slip of the tongue/indiscretion/to blurt out a secret
to let sb down/to be unfair/I'm sorry/pardon me (formal)
to talk intimately while being comparative strangers (idiom)
to force someone to do something
to forget one's manners/to forget oneself/to lose self-control (in a situation)
